Title:
Germination of the fully myco-heterotrophic orchid Cyrtosia
septentrionalis ischaracterised by low fungal specificity and does not
require direct seed-mycobiont contact
Keywords:
Armillaria, Atmospheric conditions, Galeola, Polyporales,
Symbiotic germination
Abstract:
We examined the level of specificity exhibited by seeds of
Cyrtosia septentrionalis, a fully myco-heterotrophic orchid, for
germination-inducing fungi. In addition to three wood-decomposing
Armillaria species (A. gallica, A. mellea subsp. nipponica and A.
tabescens) known to infect adult plants, a novel species of Polyporales
isolated from naturally growing protocorms was tested in a seed
germination assay. Xylobolus annosus, a free-living decomposer of
Russulales, was included as a control. Seed germination occurred in a
sawdust-based medium in sealed and unsealed containers in the presence
of all fungi, indicating low specificity for germination. Moreover,
germination did not require direct seed-fungus contact. A modified
atmosphere in the air above the inoculated medium in sealed containers,
consisting of a lower O2 and a higher CO2 concentration, was established
by the action of the fungi and brought about higher germination
percentages. In nature, atmospheric conditions more effective for seed
germination might be established by the action of mycobionts in
decomposing wood. Seeds germinated in the presence of the new
Polyporales species underwent further growth and development, as
compared with the other fungi tested, when covered with soil.
